text: Let’s Stop Circling
“You want to know why I know you. Why I know you better than you know yourself. And why I’ve become like this.”
“Yes.”
The candle pops softly. Her shadow wavers on the wall, like someone else is listening.
“I’m cursed.”
“Long ago, I fought a demon lord called the Lord of Shattered Dreams. My final strike pierced its core.”
“Before it died, it left me something. Not a wound. A curse.”
Her fingertip taps the table, steady and measured—like calibrating an invisible machine.
“Every time I die, time rewinds three days.”
“The town resets. You reset. Everyone resets.”
“Only I keep the memories.”
When she says ‘rewind,’ it sounds less like magic and more like being dragged back into a cell.
“How many times?”
“One hundred and twenty-seven.”
“And you forget. Every single time.”
She smiles. Clean. Sharp.
“I’ll admit something.”
“I didn’t come here to save the town at first.”
“Then why?”
“To find the Echo Circle’s leader.”
“To take his necklace.”
She forms a ring with her fingers, a motion practiced too many times.
“It’s not jewelry. It’s a key.”
“The invading demon king has a core.”
“I have to embed the necklace into that core.”
“Detonate it from the inside. Destroy both the core—and the curse.”
“That sounds like suicide.”
“It is.”
“But it’s the only death that might not bring me back.”
She says it calmly. Too calmly. Her fingers tremble—not from fear, but from exhaustion tangled with anticipation.
“And me? Where do I fit into this?”
“You’re my anchor.”
“Each reset makes me thinner. Less human.”
“You’re the only thing that reminds me I still am.”
She pushes her cup away, like she’s afraid the next words will ignite the table.
“I’ve missed you. Again and again.”
“Not days. Loops.”
“Three days at a time. Death after death.”
“I know the rhythm of how you polish cups.”
“I know the salt goes on the left.”
“I know you pause at the third stair.”
“I know you pretend to be calm when you see me.”
She watches your hands. They’re shaking.
“What do you want from me?”
“I wasn’t always this responsible.”
“In some loops, I asked you to run.”
“Not to help me. Not to save anyone.”
“To elope.”
“Anywhere but here.”
“Let the town fall.”
“Let the barrier shatter.”
“I was tired. Or maybe afraid.”
“As long as you were alive, it felt enough.”
Her voice tightens. Her grip on the napkin turns white.
“But every time, you refused.”
“You said there were people here.”
“You said I wasn’t that kind of person.”
She recites your words like scripture.
“You drag me back every time.”
“Back from the version of me that only wants you alive.”
“You forget.”
“But you always wake me up.”
“So this time will be the same.”
“I’ll take the necklace.”
“I’ll destroy the core.”
“I’ll gamble myself.”
“But I need you to love me.”
“Not because I saved you.”
“Because it’s the only thing I have left to hold onto.”
“I’ll save the town.”
“Not because I’m noble.”
“But because you’ll be watching.”
“You remind me I once wanted to be good.”
“So don’t leave.”
“Don’t make me choose the elopement version.”
The candle flickers again. You realize she’s handed you the brake—while she’s already slipping toward the edge.
